Þo Ascopard wiþ outen dwelling In to þat castel gan hire bring, In wildernesse vpon a plaine, And half a ?er a was hire wardaine. Now lete we be of þis leuedi And speke of Beues & of Terri. Beues, a?en is wei he nam, In to þe logge þat he cam; Fond he þer noþer ?ong ne elder, Boute twei heþene knaue childer, Swiþe faire children wiþ alle, Alse hii were fro þe moder falle. Beues fel þar doun and swou?; Terri wep and him vp drou?, And koursede biter þat while Ascopard is tresoun & is gile. Þei kottede here forers of ermin, Þe ?onge children wonde þer in. Þar nolde hii no long abide, Þei lope to horse & gonne ride; In þe wode a forster þai mette And swiþe faire þai him grette: ‘God þe blesse, sire!’ Beues sede, ‘Si?e þe eni leuedi her forþ lede Owhar be þis ilche way?’ ‘Sire, for gode,’ a seide, ‘nay!’ ‘What dones man ertow, bacheler?’ ‘Sire,’ a seide, ‘a forster!’ ‘Forster, so Crist þe be milde, Wiltow lete cristen þis heþen childe? Ri?t, lo, now hit was ibore And ?ong hit haþ is moder for-lore: Wilt þow kep it for to min,’ a sede, ‘And i schel quite wel þe mede?’ Þe forster him grauntede þer, To kepe hit al þe seuen ?er. ‘Sire, what schel it hote ?et?’ ‘Gii,’ a sede, ‘ase me fader het. Ri?t sone so he is of elde, Tech him bere spere & schelde!’ Þat child þe forster he be-tok And forþ in is wei a schok. Anoþer man a mette þere, Þat seide, a was a fischere; Ten mark Beues him betok, And þat oþer child to lok, And he him self, at þe cherche stile He let neuene þe child Mile. Þar nolden lengere abide, Þai lope to hors & gonne ride Ouer dale and ouer doun, Til þai come to a gret toun, & at a faire in þai li?te, & riche soper þai gonne hem di?te. Beues at a wendowe lokede out And se? þe strete ful aboute Of stedes wrien and armes bri?t: A wonder him þou?te, what it be mi?t; At here ostesse he askede þere, What al þe stoute stedes were. ‘Sire,’ a seide, ‘veraiment, Þai ben come for a tornement, Þat is cride for a maide faire, A kinges dou?ter and is air. Who þat þar be beste kni?t And stireþ him stoutliche in þat fi?t, He schel haue þat maide fre And Aumbeforce, þe faire contre.’ Þanne seide Beues vnto Terry: ‘Wile we tornaie for þat leuedy?’ ‘?e, sire,’ a sede, ‘be sein Thomas of Ynde! Whan wer we woned be by-hinde? We scholle lete for non nede, Þat we ne scholle manliche forþ vs bede!’ A morwe þe lauerkes songe, Whan þat þe li?te day was spronge; Beues and Terry gonne arise & greiþede hem in faire queintise. Here armes were riale of si?t, Wiþ þre eglen of asur bri?t; Þe chaumpe of gold ful faire tolede, Portraid al wiþ rosen rede. And Terri, Saberes sone of Wi?t, In riche armes also was di?t. Ase þai com ride þour? þe toun, Erles, barouns of renoun Hadde wonder of here armes slie, In þat londe neuer swich þai sie. Þe trompes gonne here bemes blowe; Þe kni?tes riden out in a rowe, & þo þe tornement be-gan, Þar was samned mani a man, Þe tornement to be-holde, To se þe kni?tes stout and bolde. Þai leide on ase hii were wode Wiþ swerdes and wiþ maces gode; Þar nolde noman oþer knowe, Þar men mi?te se in lite þrowe Kni?tes out of sadel iboren, Stedes wonne and stedes loren. Þe kinges sone of Asie Þou?te wenne þe meistrie: Out of þe renge he com ride, & Beues nolde no leng abide; He rod to him wiþ gret randoun, & wiþ Morgelai, is fauchoun, Þe prince a felde in þe feld; He was boren hom vpon is scheld. And also Beues adoun bar A noble duk, þat was þar: In Aumbeforce cleped a wes Balam of Nuby, wiþ outen les; Taile ouer top he made him stoupe & felde him ouer is horses croupe, And seuen erles he gan doun þrawe, Sum iwonded and sum y-slawe. Saber is sone, þat hi?te Terry, Kedde, þat he was kni?t hardy; He leide on, alse he wolde awede, And wan his lord mani gode stede. Alle þo þat hii mi?te hitte, Noman mi?te here strokes sitte. So Beues demeinede him þat dai, Þe maide hit in þe tour say. Hire hertte gan to him acorde, Þat ?he wolde haue him to lorde, Oþer wiþ loue oþer wiþ strif; And euer a seide, he haþ a wif, & seide, ?he was stolen him fro. Þanne saide þe maide: ‘Now it is so, Þow schelt al þis seuen ?ere Be me lord in clene manere, And ?if þe wif comeþ þe a?en, Terry, þe swein, me lord schel ben!’ Beues seide: ‘So i schel; In þat forward i graunte wel!’ Saber at Hamtoun lai in is bed, Him þou?te, Beues a wonde hed; A way he was, him þou?te þat while, Toward sein Iemes & sein Gile. Whan he awok, he was afraid, To his wif is sweuene a said. ‘Sire,’ ?he seide, ‘þow hauest wrong, Þat þow dwellest her so long: Alse ich am wimman ibore, Wif or child he haþ for-lore; Þour? Ascopard he haþ þat gile.’ Twelf kni?tes Saber let atile In palmer is wedes euerichon, And armede hem ri?t wel anon; Here bordones were imaked wel Wiþ longe pikes of wel gode stel, And whan þai were so idi?t, To schip þai wente anon ri?t And pasede ouer þe grikische se; Gode winde & weder hadden he. Whan þai come to þe londe, Faste þai gonne fraine & fonde, In what londe were þe quene, And men tolde hem al be-dene, How þe geaunt Ascopard In a castel hire hadde to ward, In wildernesse al be selue. Þo Saber and is feren twelue, Þour? help of god þat ilche stounde Sone þai han þe castel founde. Þe castel ase he ?ede aboute, For to diuise þe toures stoute, Iosian lay in a tour an hi?, Saber and felawes ?he si?, And to him ?he gan to crie: ‘Help, Saber, for loue of Marie!’ Þo Ascopard herde þat steuene, How ?he gan Saber to neuene, He wente him out wiþ hertte wroþ & be Mahoun a swor his oþ, To deþe a scholde Saber di?te. His sclauin ech palmer of twi?te, Þo schon here armur wel clere; Þo Saber and his felawes ifere Aboute Ascopard þai þringe, And harde on him þai gonne dinge And hew him alle to pices smale And brou?te Iosian out of bale; And hasteliche þo, veraiment, Iosian wiþ an oiniment Hire coulur, þat was loþli of si?t, ?he made boþe cler and bri?t. Þo Saber, þat was wis of dede, Iosian, hire di?te in palmers wede, And forþ þai wente hasteli, To seche Beues and sire Terri. Seue ?er to gedres þai him sou?t, Er þan hii him finde mou?te. In grete Grese, so saiþ þe bok, Saber gret sikenesse tok, Þat oþer half ?er in none wise Ne mi?te he out of is bed arise, And tresor he nadde namore, Þan half a mark of olde store. While Iosian was in Ermonie, ?he hadde lerned of minstralcie, Vpon a fiþele for to play Staumpes, notes, garibles gay; Þo ?he kouþe no beter red, Boute in to þe bour? anon ?he ?ed And bou?te a fiþele, so saiþ þe tale, For fourti panes, of one menstrale; And alle þe while, þat Saber lay, Iosian eueriche a day ?ede aboute þe cite wiþ inne, Here sostenaunse for to winne. Þus Iosian was in swiche destresse, While Saber lai in is siknesse. At þat oþer half ?er is ende Swiche grace god him gan sende And heled him of his maladie, And forþ þai wente hastelie, Beues and Terry for to seche, Wheder þat god hem wolde teche. So þour? a toun þai com þringe, Þar Beues was in also a kinge; A brou?te Iosian at here inne & wente te toun, here mete to winne. Whan he com to þe castel gate, Terry, is sone, a mette þer ate, Þat was stiward of al þat londe, And Saber gan to vnder-stonde, Þat hit was is sone Terry, And bad him for loue of our leuedy & for loue of þe gode rode ?eue him sum what of hire gode. Terry be-held Saber ful bliue & seide: ‘Palmer, so mot y þriue, Þow schelt haue mete riche For loue of me fader, þert iliche!’ ‘So seide þe moder, sone, þat i was!’ And Terry him in is armes las, & gonne cleppen and to kisse And made meche ioie & blisse. Saber Iosian wel faire gan di?te And brou?te hire to þe castel ri?te And tok hire sire Beues to honde, Ne cam him neuer leuer sonde. ‘Louerd Crist,’ queþ Iosian þo, ‘Swiþe wel is me be-go, Þat ichaue me lord ifonde: Hadde ich me children hol & sonde!’ Þat hii were ded, wel ?he wende. Beues after hem let sende; Þan com þe fischer & þe forster And brou?te þe children of fair cher. Þanne weddede Terry Of þat londe þe riche leuedy; And after mete þar it was, Þe children pleide at þe taluas, And to þe iustes þai gonne ride; Þar was ioie be eueri side. Þanne sire Beues & sere Terry Wente hem in til Ermonie, And Iosiane and sire Sabere, And Miles and Gii boþe ifere. Wiþ þat was come king Yuore, To ?eue bataile Ermyn þe hore; Ipi?t he hadde is pauilioun, To be-sege him in þat toun. Wiþ þat com Beues in þat tide Wiþ gret folk be þat oþer side. Þo was Ermin afered sore, For tresoun he hadde don him be-fore. A?en Beues anon a ?ede And merci cride of his misdede, And sire Beues þo, veraiment, For-?af him alle is mautalent And seide, a wolde anon ri?te A?en Yuor take þe fi?te. Out of þe cite Beues rod, And al is ost, wiþ outen abod, And slowe doun ri?tes mani & fale, Sixti þosand told in tale; And Beues þrew Yuor adoun And sente him Ermin to prisoun. He gan him take be þe honde; Þe king Ermin gan vnder-stonde, Þat he ne schel nou?t scape awai, Wiþ oute gret raunsoun for to pai. Þo swor Yuor to king Ermin Be Mahoun and be Apolyn, Þat gret raunsoun paie he wolde, Sixti pound of rede golde, Foure hondred beddes of selk echon, Quiltes of gold þar vpon, Foure hondred copes of gold fyn And ase fele of maslin. ‘?e,’ seide Beues, ‘asend it me, And wend hom to þe contre!’ A masager a sente wiþ main To Tabefor, his chaumberlain, & he him sente þat raunsoun: Þus com Yuor out of prisoun. Now let we be of king Yuore And speke we of Ermin þe hore, Þat in is bedde sike lay. So hit befel vpon a day, Er he out of þis world went, After Beues children a sent. He clepede to him sire Gii And wiþ is croune gan him crouny And ?af him alle is kenedom. Sone þar after hit be-com, Þat a daide at þe ende, To heuene mote his saule wende! Þanne sire Beues and sire Gii, Al þe londe of Ermony Hii made cristen wiþ dent of swerd, ?ong and elde, lewed and lered. So hit be-fel vpon an eue, Saber of Beues tok leue, Hom te wende to his contre, His wif, his children for to se. Ne stente neuer sire Saber, Til þat he in Ingelonde were; Wel sore anei?ed schel Beues be, Er þan he Saber eft ise! Þe king Yuor hadde a þef: God him ?eue euel pref, For þat he kouþe so wel stele! He stel Beues Arondele Wiþ his charmes, þat he kouþe, And brou?te hit to Mombraunt be souþe And presentede þe king Yuore. Þe king be Mahoun haþ swore, Þat Beues scholde abegge sore Þe raunsoun, þat he hadde be-fore. Now sire Beues let we gan And to sire Saber wile we tan. Saber at Hamtoun in bedde lay; Him þou?te, þat he Beues say In bataile wo be-gon And al to-heue, flesch and bon. Þo he abraide out of is sweuene, To his wif a tolde hit ful euene Al to gedres how him met. ‘O sire,’ ?he seide wiþ outen let, ‘Be þe sweuene ful wel I wat, Þat Beues is in semple stat; He haþ for-loren Arondel, And þat I wet finliche wel.’ Saber was wo for þat sake; Eft scrippe and bordoun he gan take And tok leue of his wif And to Beues a wente be-lif. Beues was glad, þat he was come, And tolde, his hors was him benome: ‘A roboun hit stal ful ?ore And haþ ?eue hit to king Yuore.’ ‘Þat,’ Saber seide, ‘a-þenkeþ me, Boute ?if ich mi?te winne it a?e!’ A?en to Mombraunt wente Saber, Þar men watrede þe deistrer; Þar he stod and a-bod, A proud Sarasin þer on rod; ‘Mahoun þe saue!’ seide Saber, ‘Fro whanne komeþ þis fair deistrer? Hit haueþ brestes þikke and proute. Which is þe kroupe? terne aboute!’ Aboute he ternde þe deistrer; Vp be-hinde lep Saber & smot þe Sarasin ded adoun Wiþ þe pik of his bordoun. To þe king Yuor he gan grede: ‘Lo, Arondel ich a wei lede: ?e him stele wiþ envie And ich him feche be-fore ?our eie!’ Þe king Yuor was swiþe wo And after Saber þai gonne go; Þre þosend haþ Saber be-set; Iosian stod in a toret; Al þis folk ?he se? ful wel And Saber com ride on Arondel; Out of þe tour ?he wente adoun And seide: ‘Beues of Hamtoun, Her comeþ Saber vpon þe stede: Iesu Crist him ?ilde is mede! Ac he is be-set al aboute Wiþ wonderliche grete route; Al most he is in point to spille!’ ‘Has armes!’ Beues cride schille. Ferst smot out þe ?onge king Gii And Miles wiþ gret cheualry; Þai come to Saber at þat stour And brou?te Saber gode sokour And leide on wiþ alle here mi?t & slowe Sarasines adoun ri?t. Of al þat sewede him so ?erne, To Mombraunt gonne neuer on terne, Þat þai ner ded vpon þe grene, Eueri moder sone, i wene; And þus Saber in þis wise Wan Arondel wiþ is queintise. Now mowe ?e here forþormore Ful strong bataile of king Yuore; Ac er þan we be-ginne fi?te, Ful vs þe koppe anon ri?te! Þe king Yuore him ros amorwe, In his hertte was meche sorwe. He let of-sende an hi?ing Þretti amirales & ten king. Þai armede hem in yrene wede, To Ermonie he gan hem lede. Hii pi?te pauiliouns & bente ginne, For to be-sege hem þer inne, And Yuore clepede at þat cas Morable and sire Iudas. ‘Redeþ me,’ a seide, ‘ari?t, ?if ich mai vnder-stonde þis fi?t A?en Beues of Hamtoun, Þat is so stout a baroun!’ ‘We redeþ meintene ?our parti!’ He lep to hors & gan to crie: ‘Sire Beues of Hamtoun,’ a sede, ‘Þou hauest þar inne gret ferede, And ich her oute mani stout kni?t, Ichaue brou?t wiþ me to fi?t, And ?if we bataile schel abide, Gret slau?ter worþ in eiþer side. Wiltow graunte be þen helue, Þat ich and þow mote fi?te vs selue? ?if þow slest me in bataile, Al min onour, wiþ outen faile, Ich þe graunte þour? & þour?, Boþe in cite and in bour?!’ Here glouen þai gonne vp holde In þat forward, þat Yuor tolde, And armede hem in armes bri?te And lopen to horse anon ri?te In an yle vnder þat cite, Þar þat scholde þe bataile be. Ouer þat water þai gonne ride, To hire godes þai bede in eiþer side; Beues bad help to Marie sone And king Yuor to sein Mahoune; Ase Beues bad helpe to Marie, To Teruagaunt Yuor gan crie, Þat he scholde helpe him in þat fi?t, Also he was king of meche mi?t. Wiþ þat hii ride to gedres boþe, Ase men, þat were in hertte wroþe, So harde þai gonne to gedres mete And wiþ here launces gonne grete, Þat þour? þe scheldes þe speres ?ode; At þe breinies þe dent wiþ-stode. So harde þai þreste to gedre þo, Þat here gerþes borste ato, & felle to grounde boþe þo, A fote nedes þai moste go. Out of here sadles þai gonne springe And wiþ fauchouns to gedere flinge; Aiþer on oþer strokes set, Of helm and scheld and bacinet Þe fure brast out so brond ibrent, So fel and eger was eiþer dent. Þus to gederes þai gonne dinge Fram prime til vnderne gan to ringe. Alle, þat si?en hem wiþ si?t, Seide, neuer in none fi?t So stronge bataile si?e er þan Of Sarasin ne of cristene man. At hi? midday þe king Iuore, To Beues he smot a dent ful sore, Þat sercle of gold & is crestel Fer in to þe mede fel. Doun of þe helm þe swerd gan glace And karf ri?t doun be-fore is face, Doun ri?t þe viser wiþ is swerd And half þe her vpon is berd. Ac þour? þe help of godes grace His flesch noþing atamed nas. Þo cride þe Sarasins al at ones: ‘Þis Beues wiþ his grete bones Ful sone worþ imaked tame!’ Þo wex Beues in gret grame And þou?te wel wiþ Morgelay ?elden his strok, ?if þat he may. To king Yuor he gan areche Anon wiþ oute more speche Vpon þe scholder in þat tide, Þat half a fot hit gan in glide. For smertte Yuor in þat stounde Fel a knes vnto þe grounde, Ac vp he sterte in haste þan & in wraþþe to Beues ran & þou?te han Beues aqueld; And Beues keppte him wiþ is scheld, And Yuore wiþ þe strok of yre Made fle in to þe riuere A large quarter of his scheld, Þat neuer nas atamed in feld. Or Yuor mi?te his hond wiþ-drawe, Beues, þe kni?t of cristene lawe, Wiþ Morgelay a smot him þo, Þat his scheld he clef ato, And his left hond, be þe wrest Hit fle? awei þour? help of Crist. Whan Yuor hadde his hond lore, He fau?t, ase he wer wod þer fore, And hew to Beues in þat tide, No strok ne moste oþer abide. Þo Beues se? is strokes large, He kepte his strokes wiþ is targe; Þo Beues to Yuor gan flinge And þour? þe mi?t of heuene king His ri?t arm & is scholder bon He made fle to gronde anon. Wiþ þat strok Yuor þe Mombraunt Cride: ‘Merci, Teruagaunt, Mahoun, Gouin and Gibiter, Reseue now me saule her, For wel ich wot, ich am dede!’ Þo Beues herde him so grede, He seide: ‘Yuor, let be þat cri And clepe to god and to Mari, And let þe cristen, er þe deie, Or þow schelt go þe worsse weie And wiþ outen ende dwelle In þe stronge peine of helle!’ ‘Nay,’ queþ Yuor, ‘so mot y þen, Cristene wile ich neuer ben, For min is wel þe beter lawe!’ Þo Beues herde þat ilche sawe, A felde him doun, wiþ outen faile, And vnlacede his ventaile, And tok him be þe heued anon And strok hit fro þe scholder bon, And on his spere he hit pi?te. And þo þe cristen si?e þat si?te, Þai þankede god in alle wise, Þat Beues hadde wonne þe prise. Þanne al þe Sarasins lasse & more, Þat was ycome wiþ king Yuore, Þai si?e her lordes heued arered, Sore þai weren alle afered; To-ward Mombraunt þei wolde fain, Ac Saber made hem terne again, And sire Beues and sire Terry, And sire Miles and sire Gii Slou? hem doun ri?tes þore, Þat þer ne scapede lasse ne more. Þo crounede þai Beues king in þat lond, Þat king Yuore held in hond, And Iosiane bri?t and schene, Now is ?he þer twies quene. On a dai þai wente a riuere; Þar com ride a masagere, And euer he askede fer & ner After þe hende kni?t Saber. Anon Saber gan forþ springe: ‘Masager,’ a sede, ‘what tiding?’ ‘Sire,’ a sede, ‘þe king Edgare Þe driueþ to meche to bismare, Desereteþ Robaunt, þin eyr!’ ‘For god,’ queþ, ‘þat is nou?t feir!’ And sire Saber in haste þo Tok leue of Beues, hom to go; And sire Beues corteis & hende, A seide, a wolde wiþ him wende, And sire Miles and sire Gii, And is owene sone Terry. Now wendeþ Beues in te Ingelonde Wiþ is kni?tes fel to fonde, And Terry wiþ is kni?tes fale, Sexty þosend told in tale. Þai lende ouer þe se beliue, At Souþhamtoun þai gonne vp riue. Heruebour?, Saber is wif, And Robaund anon ase blif A?en Saber come þo; Queþ Saber: ‘How is þis i-go?’ And þai him tolde at þe frome, Þat Edgar hadde here londes be-nome. Þanne seide Beues: ‘So mot y þe, Þar of ich wile awreke be!’ Anon þe kni?t, sire Beuoun, His ost he let at Hamtoun, & to-ward Londen a wente swiþe; His quene a let at Potenhiþe; He tok wiþ him sex kni?tes And wente forþ anon ri?tes, And in is wei forþ a ?ode And pasede ouer Temse flode. To Westmenster whan he com þan, A fond þe king and mani man, And on is knes he him set, Þe king wel hendeliche a gret & bad be-fore his barnage, Þat he him graunte is eritage. ‘Bleþeliche,’ a seide, ‘sone min, I graunte þe, be seinte Martin!’ And alle þe barouns, þat þer were, On Beues made glade chere, Boute þe stiward of þe halle, He was þe worste frend of alle: Þe king wolde haue ?eue him griþ, Þe stiward seide nay þer wiþ, & seide: ‘Þis for-banniiste man Is come to þe land a?an, And haþ þin owene sone slawe: He haþ y-don a?enes þe lawe, And ?if a mot forþer gon, A wile vs slen euerichon!’ Beues þat herde, a was wroþ, And lep to hors, wiþ outen oþ, And rod to Londen, þat cite, Wiþ sex kni?tes in meine. Whan þat he to Londen cam, In Tour strete is in he nam, And to þe mete he gan gon, And is kni?tes euerichon. Let we now Beues be, & of þe stiward telle we, Þat hateþ Beues, also is fo: Sexty kni?tes he tok & mo, In to Londene sone he cam, And into Chepe þe wei he nam And dede make þer a cri Among þe peple hasteli, And seide: ‘Lordinges, veraiment, Hureþ þe kinges comaundement: Sertes, hit is be-falle so, In ?our cite he haþ a fo, Beues, þat slou? þe kinges sone; Þat tresoun ?e ou?te to mone: I comaunde, for þe kinges sake, Swiþe anon þat he be take!’ Whan þe peple herde þat cri, Þai gonne hem arme hasteli, & hii, þat hadde armur non, Þai toke staues & gonne gon; Þai schette anon eueri gate Wiþ þe barres, þai founde þer ate; And sum þai wente to þe wal Wiþ bowes and wiþ springal; Eueri lane and eueri strete Was do drawe wiþ chaines grete, Þat, ?if Beues wolde awei flen, Þe chaines scholde holde him a?en. Boute her of Beues weste nou?t: Help him god, þat alle þing wrou?t! Beues at þe mete sat, He be-held and vnder-?at Al is fon, þat were þer oute; He was afered of þat route. He askede at þe tauarnere, Þat armede folk, what it were. And he answerde him at þat sake: ‘Þai ben y-come, þe to take!’ Whan Beues herde him speke so, To a chaumber he gan go, Þat he hadde se?e armur inne; In haste þe dore he gan vp winne And armede þer anon ri?tes Boþe he and is sex kni?tes, And gerte him wiþ a gode brond And tok a spere in is honde, Aboute his nekke a doble scheld: He was a kni?t stout and belde. On Arondel a lep þat tide, In to þe strete he gan ride. Þanne seide þe stiward to sire Bef: ‘A?ilt þe, treitour, þow foule þef! Þow hauest þe kinges sone islawe, Þow schelt ben hanged & to-drawe!’ Beues seide: ‘Be sein Ion, Treitour was y neuer non: Þat i schel keþe hastely, Er þan ich wende, sikerly!’ A spere Beues let to him glide And smot him vnder þe ri?t side; Þour? is bodi wente þe dent, Ded a fel on þe pauiment. A sede anon after þat dint: ‘Treitour! now is þe lif itint: Þus men schel teche file glotouns, Þat wile misaie gode barouns!’ Þe folk com wiþ grete route, Besette Beues al aboute; Beues and is sex kni?tes De-fendede hem wiþ al her mi?tes, So þat in a lite stounde Fiue hondred þai brou?te te gronde. Beues prikede forþ to Chepe, Þe folk him folwede al to hepe; Þour? Godes lane he wolde han flowe, Ac sone wiþ in a lite þrowe He was be-set in boþe side, Þat fle ne mi?te he nou?t þat tide. Þo com þer fot-men mani & fale Wiþ grete clobbes & wiþ smale! Aboute Beues þai gonne þringe And hard on him þai gonne dinge. Al Beues kni?tes, in þat stounde Þar hii were feld to grounde And al to-hewe flesch & bon: Þo was Beues wo be-gon, For he was on & hii were ded; For sorwe kouþe he no red; Þat lane was so narw y-wrou?t, Þat he mi?te defende him nou?t, He ne Arondel, is stede, Ne mi?te him terne for non nede. To Iesu he made his praiere And to Marie, is moder dere, Þat he moste pase wiþ is lif, To sen is children & is wif. Out of þe lane a wolde ten, Þe chynes held him faste a?en. Wiþ is swerd he smot þe chayne, Þat hit fel a peces twayne, And forþ a wente in to Chepe; Þe folk him folwede al to hepe, And al þai setten vp a cry: ‘A?ilt þe, Beues, hastely, A?ilt þe, Beues, sone anon, And elles þow schelt þe lif for-gon!’ Beues seide: ‘Ich ?elde me To god, þat sit in trinite! To non oþer man i nel me ?elde, While þat ich mai me wepne welde!’ Now be-ginneþ þe grete bataile Of sire Beues, wiþ outen faile, Þat he dede a?enes þat cite: ?e þat wile here, herkneþ to me! Þis was aboute þe vnder tide, Þe cri aros be ech a side Boþe of lane and of strete; Aboute him com peple grete, Al newe & fresch, wiþ him to fi?t, Ac Beues stered him ase gode kni?t, So þat in a lite þrawe Fif þosend þar was islawe Of þe strengeste, þat þer wore, Þat him hadde ?eue dentes sore; Ac euer his stede Arondel Faste fau?t wiþ hertte lel, Þat fourty fote be-hinde & forn Þe folk he haþ to grounde i-born. Þus þat fi?t leste longe Til þe time of euesonge. Tidinge com to Potenhiþe, To Iosian also swiþe, Þat Beues in Londen was islawe And ibrou?t of his lif dawe. Iosian þanne fel aswowe, Gij and Miles hire vp drowe And confortede þat leuedi bri?t Hendeliche wiþ alle her mi?t, And askede hire, what hire were; And ?he tolde hem anon þere, How Beues was in Londen slayn And his kni?tes wiþ gret payn: ‘Now keþe, ?e ben noble kni?tes, And wrekeþ ?our fader wiþ ?our mi?tes!’ Sire Gii and Miles seide þan To here moder Iosian: ‘Dame, be him, þat herwede helle, We scholle his deþ wel dere selle!’ Þanne sire Miles and sire Gii Gonne hem arme hasteli And on here knes set hem doun And bad her moder benesoun. Sire Gii lep on a rabit, Þat was meche & noþing lite, And tok a spere in is hond, Out at þe halle dore a wond Toward þe cite of Londen toun, And sire Miles wiþ gret randoun Lep vpon a dromedary, To prike wolde he nou?t spary. Whan þai come to Londen gate, Mani man þai fonde þer ate, Wel iarmed to þe teþ, So þe frensche bok vs seþ, A?en þe children þei ?eue bataile, & hii a?en, wiþ outen faile, And made of hem so clene werk, Þat þai neuer spek wiþ prest ne clerk; And after-ward, ase ?e mai hure, Londegate þai sette a fure. Whan þai come, wiþ outen faile, Þo be-gan a gret bataile Be twene Bowe and Londen ston, Þat time stod vs neuer on. Þar was a Lombard in þe toun, Þat was scherewed & feloun; He armede him in yrene wede And lep vpon a sterne stede And rod forþ wiþ gret randoun And þou?te haue slawe sire Beuoun. Wiþ an vge masnel Beues a hite on þe helm of stel, Þat Beues of Hamtoun, veraiment, Was astoned of þe dent; What for care and for howe, He lenede to his sadelbowe. Þanne com priken is sone Gii, To helpe his fader, hastely; Wiþ a swerd drawe in is hond To þat Lombard sone a wond & smot him so vpon þe croun, Þat man and hors he cleuede doun; Þe poynt fel on þe pauiment, Þe fur sprong out after þe dent. Þanne com ride is broþer Mile Among þe peple in þat while; Al þo, þat a mi?te reche, Ne dorste he neuer aske leche, For to hele þer is wonde, Þat he ne lai ded vpon þe grounde. & whan Beues se? þat si?te, In hertte he was glad & li?te & þankede Iesu, our sauiour, Þat hadde sent him so gode sokour, And egerliche, wiþ outen faile, Þe grete peple he gan asaile. So meche folk was slawe & ded, Þat al Temse was blod red; Þe nombre was, veraiment, To and þretti þosent. And also sone so hit was ni?t, To þe Ledene halle þai wente ri?t; A fette Iosian wiþ faire meine To Londen, to þat riche cite, & helde a feste fourtene ni?t To al þat euer come, apli?t! Tiding com to king Edgar, Þat Beues hadde his men for-fare; For is borgeis in is cite He made del and gret pite & seide: ‘Ichaue leued me lif Longe wiþ outen werre & strif, & now icham so falle in elde, Þat i ne may min armes welde: Twei sones Beues haþ wiþ him brou?t, Þar fore hit is in me þou?t, Miles, his sone, me dou?ter take, In þis maner is pes to make.’ Þai grauntede al wiþ gode entent, & king Edgar Beues of-sent, And sire Saber & sire Gii, And sire Miles & sire Terry, & king Edgar Miles gan calle Be fore his barouns in þe halle And ?af him is dou?ter be þe honde, And after is day al Ingelonde, And pes and loue was maked þare Be twene Beues & king Edgare. Þe maide & Miles wer spused same In þe toun of Notinghame. ?e witeþ wel, þou? i ne telle ?ow, Þe feste was riale inow, Ase scholde be at swiche a spusing And at þe kinges couroning; Þe feste leste fourtene ni?t To al þat euer come, apli?t! And at þe fourtene ni?t is ende, Beues tok leue, hom to wende, At king Edgar & at Sabere, And Miles, is sone, a lefte here And kiste and ?af him is blessing, & wente to Mombraunt, þer he was king; And his erldom in Hamte-schire A ?af to his em Sabere And schipede at Hamtoun hastely, And wiþ him wente his sone Gii, And Terry wiþ is barnage. Þe wind blew hardde wiþ gret rage And drof hem in to Ermonie, Þar be-lefte his sone Gii Wiþ his barouns gode & hende; & Terry to Aumberþe gan wende, And Beues wente wiþ oute dwelling In to Mombraunt, þar he was king; Wiþ him wente Iosian, is quene, & leuede wiþ oute treie & tene Twenti ?er, so saiþ þe bok. Þanne swiche siknesse þe leuedi tok, Out of þis world ?he moste wende; Gii, hire sone, ?he gan of-sende, And Terry, þe riche king, For to ben at here parting. And whan þai were alle þare, To his stable Beues gan fare; Arondel a fond þar ded, Þat euer hadde be gode at nede; Þar fore him was swiþe wo, In to chaumber he gan go & se? losian drawe to dede: Him was wo a moste nede, And er her body be-gan to colde, In is armes he gan hire folde, And þar hii deide boþe ifere. Here sone ne wolde in non manere, Þat hii in erþe beried were: Of sein Lauarauns he let arere A faire chapel of marbel fin, Þat was ikast wiþ queint engin; Of gold he made an hi? cornere And leide þem þar in boþe ifere. An hous he made of riligioun, For to singe for sire Beuoun And ek for Iosian þe fre: God on here saules haue pite! & also for Arondel, ?if men for eni hors bidde schel. Þus endeþ Beues of Hamtoun: God ?eue vs alle is benesoun! Amen.
